Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Wisconsin, River Falls GREAT (Graduate, Retain, Engage, Advise, Team learning) Falcon Project is designed to increase the number of graduates in Biology, Chemistry, Geology, Environmental Science, Physics, and Mathematics. The project targets students in their first two years, using proven strategies to increase student success and support to increase the retention of STEM students.

The GREAT Falcon Project takes a three-fold approach to improve STEM retention, progression, and graduation rates. First, faculty are implementing student-centered pedagogies such as research-based laboratories, Studio Physics, and Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning to increase student engagement and success in gateway STEM courses. Several of these teaching strategies are making extensive use of a new high-technology Active Learning Classroom. Second, Peer-Led Team Learning is utilized in key bottleneck courses in Chemistry and Mathematics to teach students the problem-solving skills needed in STEM. Finally, a hybrid advising system helps STEM students with academic, social, and/or financial issues. Students showing risk factors for continued retention are contacted by a retention specialist/mentor, with appropriate interventions scheduled as needed. Students who leave STEM majors and/or the university are interviewed to assess why they are leaving. The GREAT Falcon Project directly impacts 900 students per year in STEM majors and is designed to increase the number of STEM graduates by 40 per year (from the current 130 to 170 students per year) by the end of the grant period.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our major outcome from this STEP program was the finding that students who experienced a first term intervention implemented with support of our project had an increase in STEM student survival rates (probability of retention in a STEM major into junior year) from 39% to 52%. These interventions included faculty development to increase the use of best practices in instruction, peer led instruction in chemistry and physics (Peer-Led Team Learning in chemistry, Learning Assistants coupled with Studio Physics in physics, and Learning Assistants in introductory chemistry), and intrusive advising (only conducted in the first two years of the program). There were no significant differences between the interventions in their efficacy.

The GREAT Falcon Fellows program was designed as a professional learning community aimed at providing faculty development and support for transforming an instructional unit in an introductory STEM course often labeled as “gateway” course.  Eighteen STEM faculty from biology, biotechnology, chemistry, mathematics, neuroscience, and physics departments participated in the program with several participating more than once. The courses taught during the Fellows’ programming impacted over 900 students in 14 different courses with several courses modified by more than one fellow. This activity was intended to influence the whole institution and especially the STEM faculty. According to our external reviewer, it appears the STEP program did make progress in this regard. A pre- and post-survey of all STEM faculty instructional practices in 100- and 200-level courses supported a shift toward the usage of research supported instructional practices. Interviews with past program fellows illustrates a continued commitment to utilize the modified lessons and, in some cases, to create and/or share lessons. Our institution has recently formed a Center for Teaching and Learning, and it is hoped that a program like our STEP fellows program will be implemented.

Peer instruction included both Peer-Led Team Learning (PLTL) and Learning Assistants (LA). LAs were utilized in introductory physics and chemistry courses. LAs were mainly supported by the university; however, some reassigned time to support the chemistry LAs was provided through the grant. We implemented a voluntary model of PLTL whereby some students in 100- and 200 level chemistry courses could join weekly peer-led sessions. These formalized, active learning study sessions were coordinated with course instructors and a faculty coordinator. Overall, PLTL served 477 students and 38 student PLTL leaders. The intent was to have students commit to attend every session; however, the voluntary model proved to be problematic with attendance issues. For students who participated in the majority of the sessions, we found that they earned up to one grade point higher in first term chemistry courses compared to those who did not participate (or participated to a small extent). Other 100- and 200-level chemistry courses also displayed improvements for PLTL participants between 0.5 and 1 GPA units.

Upon surveying students, both participants and non-participants felt the program would be worthwhile. As a result, we shifted one of three sections of first term chemistry in the final year of the grant to include mandatory PLTL sessions by replacing faculty-led discussions with PLTL.  Mandatory and voluntary PLTL students outperformed nonPLTL students through improved performance on a common nationally normalized exam and increased course grades. As a result of this success, all General Chemistry I course faculty discussions were replaced with PLTL sessions in Fall 2020. The dean and provost have now agreed to continue funding the PLTL program for General Chemistry for the 2020-21 academic year.

Finally, we believe that the STEP program has catalyzed an institutional re-evaluation of STEM, resulting in the Wisconsin Legislature’s funding of $2 million in the current biennium for design of a new Science and Technology Innovation Center. Once designed, the Legislature will decide whether to start construction in 2021 with expected occupancy in 2023. This $111 million Science and Technology Innovation Center is designed to support modern science education at UW-River Falls and meet industry demands in STEM fields. The project will relocate science departments from the outdated facilities. Biology, chemistry, physics, and psychology/neuroscience will all be housed in the new space, which will feature 12 flexible undergraduate instructional lab suites.  Our institutional emphasis on modern teaching and learning, catalyzed through this STEP grant, played a major role in this transformative campus project.
